title: Nearly 800,000 California residents will have their power shut off to reduce the risk of wildfires
text:
Power provider PG&E has announced that it will be cutting power off for nearly 800,000 customers in California to reduce the risk of wildfires after a severe wind warning.

In the Tuesday announcement, PG&E has said some areas could see power cuts as early as Wednesday after midnight.

They said: ‘As a precautionary measure to reduce wildfire risk during the forecasted severe wind event, PG&E confirmed that it will implement a Public Safety Power Shutoff (PSPS) in portions of 34 northern, central and coastal counties, affecting electric service for nearly 800,000 customers.’

PG&E announced on Tuesday that nearly 800,000 customers in California would undergo power shut offs starting Wednesday to reduce the risk of wildfires (pictured)

Michael Lewis, PG&E’s senior vice president of Electric Operations, said: ‘The safety of our customers and the communities we serve is our most important responsibility, which is why PG&E has decided to turn power off to customers during this widespread, severe wind event.

‘We understand the effects this event will have on our customers and appreciate the public’s patience as we do what is necessary to keep our communities safe and reduce the risk of wildfire.’

California residents (pictured) have begun to prepare for the power shut offs by using generators after PG&E's announcement

The announcement explains that some customers who are not at risk for extreme weather conditions may be affected by a power shutoff because the electric system uses power lines working together across cities, counties and regions.

34 California counties have been identified as regions within the power shutoff scope, including Napa County, Sonoma County and Santa Cruz.

Although the extreme weather event is expected to last through Thursday, residents should expect extended outages because the PG&E must inspect the large number of power lines for damage before restoring power.

Some residents are objecting the power shutoffs because it could negatively affect those who have electric based medical equipment.

PG&E provided maps (pictured) showing California residents which areas will be affected by the power shut off on Wednesday

Some residents living in and around Sacramento may be affected by power shut offs (pictured)

A close up of the Sacramento area (pictured) shows the main residents targeted are on the perimeters of the city and border national forests

Residents living near national forests and forested areas near San Francisco are also at risk for power shut offs

In an effort to help affected residents, PG&E will open Community Resource Centers on Wednesday at 8am.

The company says restrooms, bottled water, charging devices for electronics and air-conditioned seating for up to 100 people will be available.

Residents have begun to prepare for the power outage by stocking up on water bottles and using generators.

PG&E, who filed for bankruptcy protection in 2019, said they will expand the practice of shutting off power in communities at risk of wildfires.

In 2018, there were 8,527 reported wildfires in California.

The city of Paradise was experienced the deadliest wildfire in the state’s history, burning homes, business and killing 85 people.
description: Power provider PG&E will be shutting off power for nearly 800,000 customers in 34 counties across California to reduce the risk of wildfires on Wednesday after reports of severe wind
